title: BISAP Score for Pancreatitis Mortality
description: Predicts mortality risk in pancreatitis with fewer variables than Ranson's. The Bedside Index for Severity in Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) allows for early identification of patients at increased risk for in-hospital mortality.

parameters.name: impaired_mental_status
parameters.description: Impaired mental status or Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) < 15

parameters.name: sirs_criteria
parameters.description: ≥2 SIRS (Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome) criteria present

parameters.name: pleural_effusion
parameters.description: Presence of pleural effusion on imaging (chest X-ray or CT)

interpretation.description: BISAP score for pancreatitis mortality risk stratification

score_ranges.description: Mild acute pancreatitis with low mortality risk
Severe acute pancreatitis with significantly increased mortality risk

interpretation.sirs_definition: SIRS criteria: ≥2 of the following: pulse >90 bpm, respirations >20/min or PaCO2 <32 mmHg, temperature >38°C or <36°C, WBC >12,000 or <4,000 cells/mm³ or >10% bands

references: Wu BU, Johannes RS, Sun X, Tabak Y, Conwell DL, Banks PA. The early prediction of mortality in acute pancreatitis: a large population-based study. Gut. 2008 Dec;57(12):1698-703.

Singh VK, Wu BU, Bollen TL, Repas K, Maurer R, Johannes RS, et al. A prospective evaluation of the bedside index for severity in acute pancreatitis score in assessing mortality and intermediate markers of severity in acute pancreatitis. Am J Gastroenterol. 2009 Apr;104(4):966-71.
Gao W, Yang HX, Ma CE. The Value of BISAP Score for Predicting Mortality and Severity in Acute Pancreatitis: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. PLoS One. 2015 Jun 22;10(6):e0130412.
formula: BISAP = Sum of present criteria (B + I + S + A + P), each worth 1 point
notes: Developed using data from ~18,000 cases of acute pancreatitis from >200 hospitals
Score ≥3 indicates severe acute pancreatitis with high mortality risk
More convenient than Ranson's criteria with fewer variables
Can be calculated within 24 hours of admission
Sensitivity of 56% and specificity of 91% for mortality prediction at cutoff ≥3
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and other assessment tools
